article:
Andrew Tate

Andrew Tate is a British-American social media personality, businessman, and former professional kickboxer. He initially gained fame through his kickboxing career, later becoming a prominent figure in online communities and social media platforms. Tate's views and statements on various topics, including politics, culture, and personal development, have been widely reported and scrutinized.

#Early life

Andrew Tate was born on December 1, 1986, in Washington, D.C., to a British mother and an American father. He moved to the United Kingdom with his family at a young age and spent most of his childhood in Luton, England. Tate developed an interest in martial arts at an early age and began training in kickboxing as a teenager.

#Kickboxing career

Tate started his professional kickboxing career in 2008, competing in various promotions, including the International Sport Karate Association (ISKA) and the World Full Contact Association (WFCA). He won several championships, including the ISKA World Full-Contact Cruiserweight Championship and the Enfusion Live World Championship. Tate's kickboxing career spanned over a decade, during which he amassed a record of 76 wins and 9 losses.

#Big Brother

In 2016, Tate participated in the British reality television show Big Brother. He entered the show on June 5, 2016, but was removed from the program on June 14, 2016, due to a video that surfaced online, showing him striking a woman with a belt. Tate claimed the video was staged and that the woman in the video was his girlfriend, who had consented to the act.

#Online ventures

##The Real World (formerly Hustler's University)

Tate founded an online platform called Hustler's University in 2020, which later rebranded as The Real World. The platform offers courses and resources on personal development, entrepreneurship, and wealth creation. Tate has promoted the platform through his social media channels, claiming it has helped thousands of people improve their lives and achieve financial success.

##War Room

Tate is also the founder of War Room, an online community and forum focused on discussing politics, culture, and personal development. The platform has gained a significant following, with many users engaging in debates and discussions on various topics.

#Views and influence

Tate has expressed views on a range of topics, including politics, feminism, and personal development. He has been critical of modern feminism and has expressed support for traditional values and masculinity. Tate's views have been met with both praise and criticism, with some accusing him of promoting misogyny and hate speech.

##Reception

Tate's views and statements have been widely reported and scrutinized by the media and online communities. Some have praised him for his honesty and willingness to challenge mainstream narratives, while others have criticized him for promoting hate speech and misogyny.

###Response

Tate has responded to criticism by claiming that his views are often misinterpreted or taken out of context. He has also accused his critics of being intolerant and attempting to silence him.

###Surveys

Surveys have shown that Tate's views and influence are widely polarizing. A survey conducted by the market research firm YouGov found that 34% of respondents viewed Tate as a positive influence, while 43% viewed him as a negative influence.

##Social media

Tate has a significant following on social media platforms, including Instagram, Twitter, and YouTube. He has used these platforms to promote his online ventures and share his views on various topics.

###Deplatforming

Tate has been deplatformed from several social media platforms, including Twitter and Instagram, due to violating their terms of service. He has accused these platforms of censorship and attempting to silence him.

#Personal life

Tate currently resides in Romania, where he has been involved in various business ventures and has become a prominent figure in online communities. He has been open about his personal life, including his relationships and his interests outside of business and social media.

#Criminal investigations and civil cases

##In Britain

###2015–2019

Tate was investigated by British authorities in 2015 for allegedly making threats against a woman. He was also accused of harassment and was issued a restraining order.

###2024–present

Tate is currently facing a civil lawsuit in Britain, filed by a woman who claims he made defamatory statements about her online.

##In Romania: 2022–present

###Arrests, investigations and asset seizures

Tate was arrested in Romania in December 2022, along with his brother and two other individuals, on suspicion of human trafficking and rape. The arrests were made by Romanian authorities, who had been investigating Tate and his associates for several months.

###Rape and human trafficking charges

Tate has been charged with rape and human trafficking, along with his brother and two other individuals. The charges relate to allegations that Tate and his associates had been exploiting women for financial gain.

###Pre-trial detention and restrictions

Tate has been held in pre-trial detention since his arrest in December 2022. He has been restricted from leaving Romania and has been banned from using social media.

###Online harassment and lawsuits

Tate has been accused of online harassment and has faced several lawsuits in Romania, filed by women who claim he made defamatory statements about them online.

article:
Dzuluinicob

Dzuluinicob, also known as the "Land of the Descendants of the Sun," is a region located in the southeastern part of the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico. The area has a rich and diverse history, with evidence of human habitation dating back to the Pre-Columbian era. This article will explore the geography, history, society, and legacy of Dzuluinicob, providing an in-depth look at this fascinating region.

# Geography

## Physical

Dzuluinicob is situated in the southeastern part of the Yucatán Peninsula, covering an area of approximately 1,500 square kilometers. The region is characterized by a low-lying terrain, with an average elevation of 100 meters above sea level. The landscape is dominated by a mix of tropical forests, savannas, and wetlands, with numerous cenotes (natural sinkholes) and caves scattered throughout the area. The climate is warm and humid, with an average annual temperature of 25°C and an average annual rainfall of 1,500 mm.

## Political

Dzuluinicob is part of the Mexican state of Quintana Roo, with the city of Felipe Carrillo Puerto serving as the regional capital. The region is divided into several municipalities, each with its own local government and administration. The Mexican federal government also has a presence in the region, with various agencies responsible for managing the area's natural resources, providing social services, and promoting economic development.

# History

## Pre-Columbian

The history of Dzuluinicob dates back to the Pre-Columbian era, with evidence of human habitation in the region dating back to the Early Classic period (200-600 AD). During this time, the area was inhabited by the Maya civilization, who built numerous cities, temples, and ceremonial centers. The Maya developed a sophisticated system of writing, architecture, and engineering, which allowed them to create complex cities like Tulum and Chichen Itza. Dzuluinicob was an important center for trade and commerce, with the Maya exchanging goods such as cotton, cacao, and obsidian with other regions.

## Columbian

The arrival of the Spanish conquistadors in the 16th century had a profound impact on the region. The Spanish brought with them diseases such as smallpox and influenza, which decimated the indigenous population. Many of the Maya were forced to convert to Christianity, and their traditional practices and customs were suppressed. The Spanish also introduced new technologies, such as iron tools and firearms, which revolutionized agriculture and warfare. During the colonial period, Dzuluinicob was part of the Captaincy General of Yucatán, a Spanish administrative division that governed the region.

# Society

The society of Dzuluinicob is characterized by a mix of indigenous and Spanish influences. The region is home to the Maya people, who have maintained many of their traditional practices and customs. The Maya are known for their expertise in farming, hunting, and handicrafts, and many still speak the Mayan language. The region is also home to a significant number of mestizos, people of mixed indigenous and Spanish ancestry, who have adopted many of the customs and traditions of the Spanish.

The economy of Dzuluinicob is primarily based on agriculture, with crops such as corn, beans, and squash being major staples. The region is also known for its production of handicrafts, such as textiles, pottery, and woodcarvings. Tourism is also an important sector, with many visitors drawn to the region's rich cultural heritage and natural beauty.

# Legacy

## Scholarly

Dzuluinicob has been the subject of numerous scholarly studies, with researchers drawn to the region's rich cultural heritage and natural beauty. The area has been the focus of archaeological excavations, which have uncovered numerous artifacts and ruins from the Pre-Columbian era. The region has also been the subject of ethnographic studies, which have documented the customs and practices of the Maya people.

The legacy of Dzuluinicob can be seen in its rich cultural heritage, which continues to inspire and influence people around the world. The region's unique blend of indigenous and Spanish influences has created a distinct cultural identity, which is reflected in its architecture, art, and literature. The natural beauty of the region has also made it a popular destination for tourists, who come to experience the area's stunning landscapes and diverse wildlife.

# Notes and references

## Explanatory footnotes

* The name "Dzuluinicob" is derived from the Mayan language, with "dzuluin" meaning "descendant" and "cob" meaning "sun".
* The region of Dzuluinicob is also known as the "Land of the Descendants of the Sun".
* The Maya civilization is known for its sophisticated system of writing, architecture, and engineering.

article:
The Woman King

The Woman King is a 2022 historical epic film directed by Gina Prince-Bythewood and written by Dana Stevens. The film is based on the true story of the Agojie, an all-female unit of warriors who protected the West African kingdom of Dahomey in the 19th century. The film stars Viola Davis, Thuso Mbedu, Lashana Lynch, Sheila Atim, and John Boyega.

#Plot

The film takes place in the 1820s and follows the story of Nanisca, the leader of the Agojie, as she trains a new generation of warriors to fight against the Oyo Empire, a rival kingdom that has been threatening Dahomey's borders. The Agojie are known for their bravery and strength, and Nanisca is determined to protect her kingdom and its people from the Oyo Empire's attacks.

As the story unfolds, Nanisca's past is revealed, showing her journey from being a young girl sold into slavery to becoming the leader of the Agojie. The film also explores the complex relationships between the Agojie and the Dahomey kingdom's ruler, King Ghezo, as well as the tension between the Agojie and the Oyo Empire.

#Cast

* Viola Davis as Nanisca, the leader of the Agojie
* Thuso Mbedu as Nawi, a young girl who joins the Agojie
* Lashana Lynch as Izogie, a skilled warrior and Nanisca's second-in-command
* Sheila Atim as Amenza, a wise and experienced warrior
* John Boyega as King Ghezo, the ruler of Dahomey

#Production

##Development

The idea for The Woman King was first conceived by actress Maria Bello, who had read about the Agojie in a book about African history. Bello was fascinated by the story of the all-female unit of warriors and saw potential for a film. She brought the idea to screenwriter Dana Stevens, who began working on the script.

Gina Prince-Bythewood was approached to direct the film, and she was immediately drawn to the project. Prince-Bythewood had previously directed films such as Love & Basketball and The Old Guard, and she saw The Woman King as an opportunity to tell a powerful and inspiring story about women.

##Filming

Principal photography for The Woman King began in November 2021 and took place in South Africa and Ghana. The film's production team worked closely with historians and cultural consultants to ensure that the film was accurate and respectful in its portrayal of African culture.

The film's action sequences were choreographed by stunt coordinator Danny Hernandez, who worked closely with the cast to create realistic and intense fight scenes. The film's cinematographer, Polly Morgan, used a combination of sweeping landscape shots and intimate close-ups to capture the beauty and emotion of the story.

##Post-production

Post-production for The Woman King took place in the spring of 2022. The film's editor, Terilyn A. Shropshire, worked closely with Prince-Bythewood to shape the film's narrative and pacing. The film's score was composed by Terence Blanchard, who incorporated traditional African music and instruments into the soundtrack.

#Release

The Woman King was released in theaters on September 16, 2022. The film premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival, where it received a standing ovation from the audience.

#Reception

##Box office

The Woman King performed well at the box office, grossing over $90 million worldwide. The film's success was seen as a major victory for women-led films, and it paved the way for future projects featuring female leads.

##Critical response

The Woman King received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the film's powerful performances, stunning action sequences, and inspiring story. The film holds a 94% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising Viola Davis's performance as Nanisca.

##Accolades

The Woman King received several award nominations, including two Academy Award nominations for Best Actress and Best Supporting Actress. The film also won several awards, including the National Board of Review Award for Best Ensemble Cast.

#Historical accuracy

##Characters

While the characters in The Woman King are fictional, they are based on real people and events. The Agojie were a real unit of female warriors who protected the Dahomey kingdom, and King Ghezo was a real ruler of Dahomey.

##Role in slavery

The film's portrayal of the transatlantic slave trade has been praised for its accuracy and sensitivity. The film shows the devastating impact of slavery on African communities and the ways in which the slave trade was used to exploit and oppress African people.

#Controversy

Some critics have argued that The Woman King glosses over the role of the Dahomey kingdom in the transatlantic slave trade. While the film does show the kingdom's involvement in the slave trade, some have argued that it does not go far enough in condemning the kingdom's actions.

#Notes

The Woman King is a powerful and inspiring film that tells the story of a group of women who fought against oppression and exploitation. The film's success has paved the way for future projects featuring women-led casts and has inspired a new generation of filmmakers and actors.

#References

(None)

#Further reading

* "The Dahomey Warriors: Women Soldiers in West Africa" by Catherine Higgs
* "African Women in the Atlantic Slave Trade" by Herbert S. Klein and Stanley L. Engerman
* "The Woman King: A Novel" by Oyedotun Damilola Muees

#External links

* Official website

article:
Russell Brand
================

Russell Edward Brand is a British comedian, actor, television host, radio host, writer, and activist. Born on June 4, 1975, in Grays, Essex, England, Brand has become one of the most recognizable and influential figures in British popular culture.

Early Life
-----------

Brand was born to Barbara Elizabeth (née Nichols) and Ronald Henry Brand, a photographer. His parents divorced when he was six months old, and he was raised by his mother in a council flat in Grays. Brand's early life was marked by difficulties, including his mother's struggles with cancer and his own experiences with bullying at school.

Career
--------

### Stand-up

Brand began his career in comedy in the late 1990s, performing stand-up in London comedy clubs. He gained recognition for his unique style, which blended humor with philosophical and social commentary. In 2000, he won the Hackney Empire New Act of the Year award, which helped launch his career.

### Presenting

Brand's television presenting career began in 2001 with the MTV show "Dancefloor Chart." He went on to host several other shows, including "Big Brother's Big Mouth" and "The Russell Brand Show" on Channel 4. In 2008, he hosted the MTV Video Music Awards, which sparked controversy due to his off-color humor and criticism of the Bush administration.

### Acting

Brand has appeared in numerous films, including "Forgetting Sarah Marshall," "Get Him to the Greek," and "Arthur." He has also had roles in television shows such as "Saturday Night Live" and "EastEnders."

### Production

In 2008, Brand founded the production company Vanity Projects, which has produced several of his television shows and films.

### Radio

Brand has hosted several radio shows, including "The Russell Brand Show" on BBC Radio 2 and "The Trews" on Radio X.

### Podcast

In 2013, Brand launched the podcast "The Trews," which features discussions on politics, philosophy, and social issues.

### Writing

Brand has written several books, including "My Booky Wook" and "Revolution." He has also written articles for publications such as The Guardian and The New Statesman.

### Product Promotion

Brand has been involved in several product endorsement deals, including a campaign for the clothing brand Puma.

Sexual Misconduct Allegations
-----------------------------

### Pre–2023 Allegations

Brand has faced several allegations of sexual misconduct throughout his career. In 2013, he was accused of making inappropriate comments to a female journalist during an interview. He apologized for his behavior, stating that he had "crossed a line."

### Sunday Times/Channel 4 Investigation (2023)

In September 2023, an investigation by The Sunday Times and Channel 4 alleged that Brand had committed multiple instances of sexual misconduct, including rape and assault. The allegations spanned several decades and involved multiple women.

#### Release

The investigation was released in a series of articles and a documentary on Channel 4. The allegations sparked widespread outrage and calls for Brand to be held accountable.

#### Reactions and Aftermath

Brand's team denied the allegations, stating that they were "false" and "malicious." However, several of Brand's colleagues and friends came forward to corroborate the allegations.

#### Police and Legal Actions

The Metropolitan Police Service launched an investigation into the allegations, and several women came forward to make formal complaints. Brand's lawyers stated that he would cooperate fully with the investigation.

Political Activism
------------------

### 2009–2012: Early Interventions

Brand's interest in politics began in the late 2000s, when he started attending anti-war protests and speaking out against government policies. In 2010, he appeared at the Liberal Democrats' annual conference, where he advocated for electoral reform.

### 2013: New Statesman, Newsnight

In 2013, Brand wrote an article for The New Statesman, in which he argued that voting was a waste of time and that revolution was the only way to bring about change. He also appeared on the BBC's Newsnight program, where he clashed with host Jeremy Paxman over his views on politics and voting.

### 2014–2017: The Trews and Revolution

In 2014, Brand launched the YouTube series "The Trews," which featured discussions on politics, philosophy, and social issues. He also wrote the book "Revolution," which outlined his vision for a more equitable and just society.

### 2021–Present: Conspiracy Theory Accusations and Stay Free

In 2021, Brand faced criticism for promoting conspiracy theories about COVID-19 and vaccinations. He responded by launching the podcast "Stay Free," which focuses on issues such as freedom of speech and government overreach.

Personal Life
-------------

### Relationships

Brand has been in several high-profile relationships, including with celebrities such as Kate Moss and Katy Perry.

### Alleged Battery and Criminal Damage Charges

In 2008, Brand was charged with battery and criminal damage after allegedly attacking a photographer. He pleaded guilty and was fined.

### Illegal Drug Use

Brand has been open about his struggles with addiction and has spoken publicly about his experiences with illegal drugs.

Filmography
------------

### Film

* Forgetting Sarah Marshall (2008)
* Get Him to the Greek (2010)
* Arthur (2011)

### Television

* Big Brother's Big Mouth (2004–2007)
* The Russell Brand Show (2006–2008)
* Saturday Night Live (2008)
* EastEnders (2009)

Awards
--------

* Hackney Empire New Act of the Year (2000)
* MTV Europe Music Awards, Best Comedian (2006)

Stand-up DVDs
--------------

* Live (2006)
* Doing Life (2007)
* Scandalous (2009)

Written Works
--------------

* My Booky Wook (2007)
* Articles of Faith (2008)
* Revolution (2014)

Notes
-----

This article is a comprehensive overview of Russell Brand's life and career. It includes information on his early life, career, and personal life, as well as his political activism and controversies.

References
----------

Further Reading
----------------

2022 National Bank Open – Women's singles

The 2022 National Bank Open – Women's singles was the women's singles tennis tournament at the 2022 National Bank Open. It was the 120th edition of the Canadian Open and a WTA 1000 tournament on the 2022 WTA Tour. The tournament was held on outdoor hard courts at the Sobeys Stadium in Toronto, Canada.

# Seeds

Świątek then defeated Ajla Tomljanović, 6–1, 6–2.

Badosa then defeated Catherine McNally, 6–1, 6–1. 
Badosa was then defeated by Beatriz Haddad Maia, 2–6, 6–4, 6–2.

### Section 4

Jessica Pegula defeated Sloane Stephens, 2–6, 6–4, 7–5. 
Pegula then defeated Camila Giorgi, 6–2, 0–6, 7–6(7–5). 
Pegula was then defeated by Beatriz Haddad Maia, 6–3, 4–6, 6–2.

article:
Music Written in All Major or Minor Keys

Music written in all major or minor keys refers to a collection of musical pieces that cover all 24 keys, typically consisting of 12 major and 12 minor keys. This concept has been explored by numerous composers throughout history, resulting in various sets of music that showcase the entire range of tonal possibilities.

# Notable Sets that Cover All 24 Keys

Several composers have written notable sets of music that cover all 24 keys. Some of these sets are discussed below:

## Composers Who Wrote Multiple Sets

Some composers have written multiple sets of music that cover all 24 keys. For example, Johann Sebastian Bach wrote two sets of preludes and fugues, "The Well-Tempered Clavier," Books I and II, which together cover all 24 keys. Similarly, Dmitri Shostakovich wrote two sets of preludes, Opp. 34 and 87, which also cover all 24 keys.

# Variants

In addition to sets of music that cover all 24 keys, there are also variants that explore different aspects of tonality.

## Single Pieces that Modulate Through Many Keys

Some composers have written single pieces that modulate through many keys, often showcasing the composer's technical skill and creativity. For example, Franz Liszt's "La Campanella" is a piano piece that modulates through numerous keys, creating a sense of tonal uncertainty.

## Works Covering All Eight Church Modes

Some composers have written music that covers all eight church modes, which were used in medieval and Renaissance music. For example, the "Magnificat" by Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina is a famous example of a work that uses all eight church modes.

## Other Sets of 24 Pieces

In addition to sets of music that cover all 24 keys, there are also other sets of 24 pieces that explore different aspects of music. For example, the "24 Caprices" by Niccolò Paganini are a set of virtuosic pieces for solo violin that explore different technical challenges.

# Keys

The order of keys in published works can vary, depending on the composer's intentions and the historical context.

## Order of Keys in Published Works

In some cases, the order of keys in published works is determined by the composer's intention to create a sense of tonal progression or contrast. For example, in Bach's "The Well-Tempered Clavier," the order of keys is determined by the circle of fifths, creating a sense of tonal progression from key to key. In other cases, the order of keys may be determined by the publisher or editor, rather than the composer.

# History

The concept of music written in all major or minor keys has a long and varied history.

## Bach and His Precursors

Johann Sebastian Bach was one of the first composers to write music that covered all 24 keys. His "The Well-Tempered Clavier," Books I and II, are considered some of the most important works of the Baroque period. However, Bach was not the first composer to explore the concept of music written in all major or minor keys. For example, the composer and theorist Andreas Werckmeister wrote a set of preludes and fugues in all 24 keys, which was published in 1681.

## After Bach

After Bach, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continued to evolve.

### 18th and 19th Centuries

In the 18th and 19th centuries, numerous composers wrote music that covered all 24 keys. For example, Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven all wrote sets of piano sonatas that covered a range of keys.

#### 1750–1850

During this period, the Classical and Romantic periods, composers continued to explore the concept of music written in all major or minor keys. For example, the composer and pianist Muzio Clementi wrote a set of "Gradus ad Parnassum," which covered all 24 keys and was intended as a teaching tool for pianists.

#### 1851–1900

In the late 19th century, composers such as Liszt and Brahms continued to write music that covered all 24 keys. For example, Liszt's "La Campanella" is a famous example of a piece that modulates through numerous keys.

### 20th Century

In the 20th century, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continued to evolve.

#### 1901–1950

During this period, composers such as Debussy, Ravel, and Bartók wrote music that explored new and experimental approaches to tonality. For example, Debussy's "Preludes" are a set of pieces that cover a range of keys and explore new and experimental approaches to tonality.

#### 1951–2000

In the second half of the 20th century, composers such as Shostakovich, Prokofiev, and Messiaen continued to write music that covered all 24 keys. For example, Shostakovich's "Preludes and Fugues" are a set of pieces that cover all 24 keys and explore new and experimental approaches to tonality.

### 21st Century

In the 21st century, the concept of music written in all major or minor keys continues to evolve.

Composers such as Arvo Pärt, John Adams, and Thomas Adès have written music that explores new and experimental approaches to tonality. For example, Pärt's "Tabula Rasa" is a piece that explores new and experimental approaches to tonality and covers a range of keys.

Viktor An

Viktor An is a Russian short track speed skater of South Korean origin. He is one of the most decorated athletes in the history of the sport, with six Olympic gold medals, three silver, and a bronze. An has also won 37 World Championship titles, the most of any short track skater. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest short track speed skaters of all time.

# Early life and education

Viktor An was born Ahn Hyun-soo on November 23, 1985, in Seoul, South Korea. He began skating at the age of six, and his parents encouraged him to pursue the sport. An's early training took place at the Dongdaemun Ice Rink in Seoul, where he was coached by Yoon Tae-jong. An attended the Korea National Sport University (KNSU) from 2002 to 2006, where he earned a degree in physical education.

# Career

## 2000s

### Early career and the 2002 Winter Olympics

An made his international debut at the 2001 World Junior Championships in Warsaw, Poland, where he won a bronze medal in the 1500 meters. He was selected for the South Korean team for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, Utah, where he won a gold medal in the 1000 meters and a bronze in the 5000 meters relay.

#### National team 'recommendation system'

In South Korea, the national team selection process was based on a "recommendation system," where coaches and officials would recommend athletes for the national team. An was fortunate to have the support of his coach, Yoon Tae-jong, and other influential figures in the sport.

In early 2008, An suffered a serious knee injury, which forced him to undergo surgery and miss several months of competition. The injury was a major setback for An, who had been dominating the sport for several years.

Chess World Cup 2023

The Chess World Cup 2023 is a 128-player single-elimination tournament organized by the Fédération Internationale des Échecs (FIDE). The event is part of the World Chess Championship cycle and will feature some of the world's top chess players competing for the championship title and a significant prize fund.

Format

The Chess World Cup 2023 is a knockout tournament, where players are paired against each other in a series of matches. Each match consists of two classical games, with the winner being the first player to score 1.5 points or more. If the score is tied after the two classical games, the players will play a series of rapid and blitz tiebreak games to determine the winner.

Schedule

The Chess World Cup 2023 will take place from July 29 to August 24, 2023, in Baku, Azerbaijan. The tournament will consist of eight rounds, with the first round starting on July 29 and the final round taking place on August 24.

Prize money

The total prize fund for the Chess World Cup 2023 is $1.5 million, with the winner receiving $80,000 and the runner-up receiving $50,000. The prize money will be distributed among the players as follows:

* Winner: $80,000
* Runner-up: $50,000
* Third place: $30,000
* Fourth place: $20,000
* Fifth-eighth place: $15,000
* Ninth-sixteenth place: $10,000
* Seventeenth-thirty-second place: $7,000
* Thirty-third-sixty-fourth place: $5,000

Participants

The Chess World Cup 2023 will feature 128 players from around the world, including some of the top-ranked chess players. The participants will include:

* The top 20 players in the FIDE world rankings
* The winners of the FIDE Continental Championships
* The winners of the FIDE World Cup qualifiers
* The top-ranked players from each FIDE zone

Qualifier explanation

The FIDE World Cup qualifiers are a series of tournaments held around the world to determine the participants in the Chess World Cup. The qualifiers are open to all players, and the top players from each qualifier will earn a spot in the Chess World Cup.

Replacements

article:
Lafayette Ronald Hubbard, better known as L. Ron Hubbard, was an American author, philosopher, and the founder of Scientology. Born on March 13, 1911, in Tilden, Nebraska, Hubbard rose to prominence in the early 20th century as a science fiction writer, before developing the self-help system Dianetics and later the Church of Scientology.

# Life

## Before Dianetics

### Pre-war fiction

Hubbard began his writing career at an early age, publishing his first story, "The Green God," in 1934. He went on to write numerous science fiction and fantasy stories, including "Fear" and "Typewriter in the Sky," which were published in various pulp magazines. Hubbard's writing style was influenced by the likes of H.G. Wells and Jules Verne, and his stories often featured themes of adventure, technology, and the supernatural.

### Military career

In 1941, Hubbard joined the United States Navy, where he served as a lieutenant during World War II. He was injured in a ship collision and spent several months in a naval hospital, where he began to develop his ideas about the mind and human behavior. Hubbard was honorably discharged from the Navy in 1945.

### After the war

After the war, Hubbard returned to writing, producing a series of science fiction and fantasy novels, including "Slaves of Sleep" and "The End is Not Yet." He also began to develop his ideas about the human mind and behavior, which would eventually lead to the creation of Dianetics.

## In the Dianetics era

In 1950, Hubbard published his self-help book "Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health," which introduced his concept of the "reactive mind" and the "auditing" process. The book was a surprise success, and Hubbard quickly established the Hubbard Dianetic Research Foundation to promote and teach his methods.

However, the success of Dianetics was short-lived, and the foundation was plagued by financial and organizational problems. Hubbard's ideas were also met with skepticism by the scientific community, and he faced criticism for his lack of formal training in psychology or medicine.

## Pivot to Scientology

In the early 1950s, Hubbard began to develop his ideas about the nature of the universe and human spirituality, which would eventually lead to the creation of Scientology. He introduced the concept of the "thetan," a spiritual being that inhabits the body, and developed the "E-meter," a device used to measure spiritual energy.

In 1954, Hubbard established the first Church of Scientology in Los Angeles, and he quickly attracted a loyal following of adherents. Scientology was initially presented as a scientific and philosophical system, rather than a religious one, but it would eventually come to be recognized as a distinct religion.

## In the Church of Scientology era

During the 1960s and 1970s, Hubbard expanded the Church of Scientology, establishing missions and churches around the world. He also developed the "Bridge to Total Freedom," a series of spiritual exercises and courses designed to help adherents achieve spiritual enlightenment.

However, Hubbard's leadership of the church was also marked by controversy and authoritarianism. He was known for his strict control over the church's finances and operations, and he was accused of exploiting and mistreating his followers.

## In the Sea Org era

In the late 1960s, Hubbard established the Sea Organization, a paramilitary group within the Church of Scientology that was dedicated to promoting and defending the church's interests. The Sea Org was known for its strict discipline and authoritarianism, and it was accused of engaging in harassment and intimidation tactics against critics and former members.

Hubbard himself became increasingly reclusive during this period, living on a yacht and communicating with his followers through a series of written directives and taped lectures.

## In hiding

In the 1980s, Hubbard went into hiding, reportedly to avoid prosecution for his involvement in a series of financial and tax scandals. He died on January 24, 1986, at the age of 74, and his death was met with widespread speculation and conspiracy theories.

# Sources and doctrines

Hubbard's ideas about the mind, human behavior, and spirituality are based on a range of sources, including Eastern philosophy, Western psychology, and science fiction. He was influenced by the likes of Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, and Alfred Korzybski, and he drew on a range of spiritual and philosophical traditions, including Buddhism, Taoism, and Gnosticism.

At the heart of Hubbard's system is the concept of the "thetan," a spiritual being that inhabits the body and is capable of spiritual growth and development. Hubbard also developed the "E-meter," a device used to measure spiritual energy, and the "auditing" process, a technique used to help individuals overcome spiritual and emotional blockages.

# False biographical claims

Hubbard made a number of false biographical claims throughout his life, including claims to have been a decorated war hero and a successful businessman. He also exaggerated his educational credentials and his involvement in various scientific and philosophical organizations.

These claims were often used to promote Hubbard's ideas and to attract followers, but they have been widely debunked by critics and former members.

# Legacy

## In Scientology

Hubbard's legacy is still celebrated within the Church of Scientology, where he is revered as a spiritual leader and a visionary. His ideas and writings continue to be studied and promoted by adherents around the world, and his image and likeness are still used to promote the church's interests.

## In popular culture

Hubbard's ideas and legacy have also had a significant impact on popular culture, influencing a range of artists, writers, and musicians. His concepts of the "thetan" and the "E-meter" have been referenced in countless films, books, and TV shows, and his ideas about the nature of the universe and human spirituality continue to be explored and debated.

2022 Johor state election

The 2022 Johor state election was held on 12 March 2022 to elect the members of the 15th Johor State Legislative Assembly, the legislature of the Malaysian state of Johor. The election was called following the dissolution of the assembly on 22 January 2022, which was announced by the Sultan of Johor, Sultan Ibrahim Ismail. This was the first time a state election was held in Malaysia during the COVID-19 pandemic.

# Election cycles

The Johor state election is held every five years, as mandated by the Malaysian Constitution. The previous state election was held in 2018, and the current term of the assembly was set to expire on 28 June 2023. However, the Sultan of Johor, Sultan Ibrahim Ismail, dissolved the assembly on 22 January 2022, paving the way for fresh elections.

# Electoral system

The Johor state election uses a first-past-the-post electoral system, where the candidate with the most votes in each constituency is declared the winner. The election is held across 56 constituencies, each representing a single seat in the Johor State Legislative Assembly. The assembly is unicameral, meaning it has only one chamber.

# Constituencies

The 56 constituencies in Johor are divided into several regions, including the city of Johor Bahru, the towns of Batu Pahat, Muar, and Pontian, and the districts of Segamat, Kluang, and Kota Tinggi. Each constituency has a population of approximately 20,000 to 30,000 voters.

# Composition before dissolution

Before the dissolution of the assembly, the composition of the Johor State Legislative Assembly was as follows:

* Barisan Nasional (BN): 29 seats
* Pakatan Harapan (PH): 27 seats
* Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS): 1 seat

# Timeline

## Events from the Dissolution of the Johor State Legislative Assembly to the Issue of the Writ of Election (22 January to 9 February 2022)

The Sultan of Johor, Sultan Ibrahim Ismail, dissolved the Johor State Legislative Assembly on 22 January 2022, paving the way for fresh elections. The dissolution was announced in a statement by the Johor State Secretary, Azmi Rohani.

On 26 January 2022, the Election Commission of Malaysia (EC) announced that the writ of election would be issued on 9 February 2022. The EC also announced that the nomination day would be held on 26 February 2022, and the polling day would be held on 12 March 2022.

## Events from the Issue of the Writ of Election to the Nomination Day (10 to 26 February 2022)

The writ of election was issued on 9 February 2022, marking the start of the election campaign period. The EC also announced that the early polling day for postal and advance voters would be held on 8 March 2022.

On 15 February 2022, the EC announced that a total of 2,444,233 voters were eligible to cast their ballots in the election. The EC also announced that 56 candidates would be contesting in the election.

## Events from the Nomination Day to the Early Polling Day for Postal and Advance Voters & Campaigning Period (27 February to 12 March 2022)

The nomination day was held on 26 February 2022, where a total of 239 candidates submitted their nomination papers. The EC announced that a total of 56 candidates were contesting in the election, with 14 candidates from Barisan Nasional, 11 candidates from Pakatan Harapan, and 10 candidates from the Malaysian Islamic Party.

The early polling day for postal and advance voters was held on 8 March 2022. A total of 21,433 voters cast their ballots on the early polling day.

The campaigning period ended on 11 March 2022, with all candidates and parties making their final pitches to voters.

# Electoral candidates

A total of 239 candidates contested in the election, representing 14 parties and 2 independent candidates. The breakdown of candidates by party is as follows:

* Socialist Party of Malaysia (PSM): 2 candidates
* Parti Sosialis Malaysia (PAS): 1 candidate
* Independent: 2 candidates

# Results

The results of the election were as follows:

* Barisan Nasional (BN): 40 seats
* Pakatan Harapan (PH): 12 seats
* Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS): 4 seats

## By parliamentary constituency

The results by parliamentary constituency were as follows:

* Johor Bahru: Barisan Nasional (BN) won 6 seats
* Batu Pahat: Barisan Nasional (BN) won 4 seats
* Muar: Barisan Nasional (BN) won 3 seats
* Pontian: Barisan Nasional (BN) won 2 seats
* Segamat: Barisan Nasional (BN) won 2 seats
* Kluang: Barisan Nasional (BN) won 2 seats
* Kota Tinggi: Barisan Nasional (BN) won 1 seat

## Seats that changed allegiance

A total of 12 seats changed allegiance in the election. The breakdown of seats that changed allegiance is as follows:

* Barisan Nasional (BN) gained 11 seats from Pakatan Harapan (PH)
* Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS) gained 2 seats from Pakatan Harapan (PH)

# Election pendulum

The election pendulum shows the number of seats that changed allegiance in the election. The pendulum is as follows:

* Barisan Nasional (BN) +11
* Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS) +2
* Pakatan Harapan (PH) -13

# Departing incumbents

A total of 10 incumbents did not defend their seats in the election. The breakdown of departing incumbents is as follows:

* Barisan Nasional (BN): 4 incumbents did not defend their seats
* Pakatan Harapan (PH): 3 incumbents did not defend their seats
* Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS): 2 incumbents did not defend their seats
* Parti Keadilan Rakyat (PKR): 1 incumbent did not defend their seat

# Controversies and issues

The election was marred by several controversies and issues, including:

* Allegations of vote-buying and corruption
* Claims of irregularities in the electoral roll
* Accusations of bias by the Election Commission of Malaysia
* Concerns over the safety of voters and candidates

# Aftermath

The election resulted in a landslide victory for Barisan Nasional, with the coalition winning 40 seats. Pakatan Harapan won 12 seats, while the Malaysian Islamic Party won 4 seats.

The results of the election were seen as a significant setback for Pakatan Harapan, which had been hoping to make gains in the state. The coalition's poor performance was attributed to several factors, including internal conflicts and a lack of effective campaigning.

Barisan Nasional's victory was seen as a major boost for the coalition, which had been struggling to regain its footing after the 2018 general election. The coalition's victory was attributed to its effective campaigning and its ability to capitalize on the weaknesses of its opponents.

article:
2023 Israeli Judicial Reform

The 2023 Israeli judicial reform refers to a set of proposed changes to the Israeli judicial system, which were introduced by the Israeli government in 2023. The reforms aim to modify the country's system of judicial review, alter the process of judicial selection, and reduce the powers of the Supreme Court. The proposals have been met with widespread controversy and opposition from various sectors of Israeli society, as well as from the international community.

# Background

## Israeli Supreme Court and judicial review

The Israeli Supreme Court is the highest court in Israel and plays a crucial role in the country's system of judicial review. The court has the power to review and strike down laws and government decisions that are deemed unconstitutional or unreasonable. This power is based on the Israeli Basic Laws, which serve as the country's de facto constitution. The Supreme Court has used its powers of judicial review to shape Israeli law and policy on various issues, including human rights, administrative law, and the separation of powers.

## 1992 Constitutional Revolution and its discontents

The 1992 Constitutional Revolution was a major turning point in Israeli constitutional law. The Supreme Court, led by Chief Justice Aharon Barak, issued a series of landmark decisions that expanded the court's power of judicial review and established the principle of constitutional supremacy. The court's decisions were seen as a significant shift towards a more liberal and activist approach to constitutional interpretation. However, the Constitutional Revolution also generated controversy and criticism, particularly from right-wing and religious sectors of Israeli society. Some critics argued that the court had overstepped its bounds and was interfering with the democratic process.

## 2018–2022 Israeli political crisis and 2022 legislative election

The 2018–2022 Israeli political crisis was a period of prolonged political instability, marked by a series of inconclusive elections and failed coalition negotiations. The crisis was fueled by deep divisions within Israeli society, particularly on issues related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, religious freedom, and the role of the judiciary. The 2022 legislative election resulted in a narrow victory for the right-wing Likud party, led by Benjamin Netanyahu, who formed a coalition government with several smaller right-wing and religious parties. The new government vowed to implement significant reforms to the Israeli judicial system, which it saw as a major obstacle to its policy agenda.

# Legislative history

## HCJ 5658/23 Movement for Quality Government in Israel v. Knesset (2024)

The proposed judicial reforms were introduced in the Knesset in 2023, as part of a broader legislative package aimed at overhauling the Israeli judicial system. The reforms were met with fierce opposition from various sectors of Israeli society, including the Movement for Quality Government in Israel, a non-profit organization that advocates for good governance and the rule of law. The organization petitioned the Supreme Court to strike down the reforms, arguing that they were unconstitutional and would undermine the independence of the judiciary. The court is expected to hear the petition in 2024.

# Proposed changes

## Judicial selection

### Current system

The current system of judicial selection in Israel is based on a panel of nine members, including three Supreme Court justices, two ministers, two Knesset members, and two representatives of the Israel Bar Association. The panel recommends candidates for appointment to the Supreme Court, and the president of Israel makes the final appointment.

### Proposed system

The proposed reforms would give the government a majority on the judicial selection panel, allowing it to appoint judges who are more sympathetic to its policy agenda. The reforms would also introduce a new requirement that judges must have a " Zionist" worldview, which critics argue is a thinly veiled attempt to exclude judges who are seen as too liberal or left-wing.

### Arguments in favor of the reform

Proponents of the reform argue that the current system of judicial selection is flawed and allows the judiciary to appoint judges who are out of touch with the views of the Israeli public. They argue that the reforms would introduce greater diversity and balance to the judiciary, and would ensure that judges are more accountable to the elected government.

### Arguments against the reform

Critics of the reform argue that it would undermine the independence of the judiciary and allow the government to appoint judges who are beholden to its interests. They argue that the reforms would erode the rule of law and damage the reputation of the Israeli judiciary.

## Government legal advisors

The proposed reforms would also give the government greater control over the appointment of government legal advisors, who play a crucial role in advising the government on legal matters. The reforms would allow the government to appoint advisors who are more sympathetic to its policy agenda, which critics argue would undermine the independence of the legal advice given to the government.

## Constitutional review

The proposed reforms would limit the power of the Supreme Court to review and strike down laws and government decisions that are deemed unconstitutional. The reforms would introduce a new requirement that the court must have a supermajority of 80% to strike down a law, which critics argue would make it virtually impossible for the court to exercise its power of judicial review.

## Override clause

The proposed reforms would also introduce an override clause, which would allow the Knesset to override a Supreme Court decision striking down a law. The clause would allow the Knesset to reenact a law that has been struck down by the court, provided that it has a majority of 61 votes.

## Abolition of "unreasonableness" grounds

The proposed reforms would abolish the grounds of "unreasonableness" as a basis for judicial review. The reforms would argue that the court should only review laws and government decisions on grounds of constitutional validity, rather than on grounds of reasonableness.

### Arguments in favor of the reform

Proponents of the reform argue that the grounds of unreasonableness are too vague and allow the court to interfere with the democratic process. They argue that the reforms would ensure that the court only reviews laws and government decisions on clear constitutional grounds.

### Arguments against the reform

Critics of the reform argue that the abolition of the grounds of unreasonableness would undermine the power of the court to review and strike down laws and government decisions that are arbitrary or capricious. They argue that the reforms would erode the rule of law and damage the reputation of the Israeli judiciary.

## Status of the Attorney-General

The proposed reforms would also affect the status of the Attorney-General, who is the chief legal advisor to the government. The reforms would allow the government to appoint an Attorney-General who is more sympathetic to its policy agenda, which critics argue would undermine the independence of the legal advice given to the government.

# Reactions

## National

The proposed reforms have been met with fierce opposition from various sectors of Israeli society, including the judiciary, the legal profession, and civil society organizations. Critics argue that the reforms would undermine the independence of the judiciary and erode the rule of law.

## International

The proposed reforms have also been criticized by the international community, including the European Union and the United States. Critics argue that the reforms would damage the reputation of the Israeli judiciary and undermine the country's commitment to the rule of law.

## Connection to the Israeli–Palestinian conflict

The proposed reforms have also been linked to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, with critics arguing that they would allow the government to implement policies that are detrimental to the rights of Palestinian citizens of Israel. Proponents of the reforms argue that they would allow the government to implement policies that are necessary to ensure the security and well-being of the Israeli public.

# Suspension and overruling

The proposed reforms are currently being debated in the Knesset, and it is unclear whether they will be passed into law. Critics of the reforms have vowed to challenge them in the Supreme Court, and it is possible that the court may strike down some or all of the reforms.

# See also

* Israeli Supreme Court

* Constitutional law
* Israeli-Palestinian conflict

Technoblade
================

Technoblade was an American YouTube personality and gamer known for his Minecraft gameplay and commentary. He gained a large following online and became one of the most popular Minecraft YouTubers of all time.

Internet career
================

Technoblade began his YouTube career in 2012, initially creating content focused on Let's Play videos of various video games, including Minecraft. Over time, he shifted his focus primarily to Minecraft, creating content around the game's PvP (player versus player) mode. His commentary and skill in the game helped him gain a large following, and he became known for his dry wit and satirical humor.

As his channel grew in popularity, Technoblade began to collaborate with other Minecraft YouTubers, including popular players like Dream and GeorgeNotFound. He also participated in various Minecraft tournaments and events, further increasing his visibility within the gaming community.

Technoblade's content was not limited to Minecraft gameplay. He also created videos on other topics, such as his personal life and interests outside of gaming. This helped to humanize him and create a stronger connection with his audience.

Personal life
==============

Little is known about Technoblade's personal life, as he kept his real name and identity private. He rarely spoke about his personal life in his videos, preferring to focus on his gaming content. However, he did occasionally share glimpses into his life outside of gaming, including his interests in music and reading.

Despite his private nature, Technoblade was open about his struggles with anxiety and depression. He spoke publicly about his experiences with mental health, using his platform to raise awareness and reduce stigma around mental illness.

Cancer diagnosis and death
==========================

In August 2021, Technoblade announced that he had been diagnosed with sarcoma, a type of cancer. He underwent treatment and surgery, but unfortunately, the cancer had spread, and he passed away on June 30, 2022, at the age of 23.

## Reactions and tributes

The news of Technoblade's passing sent shockwaves through the gaming community, with fans and fellow YouTubers expressing their condolences and tributes on social media. Many Minecraft players and content creators shared their own stories and memories of Technoblade, celebrating his life and legacy.

The Minecraft community came together to pay their respects, with many players creating in-game tributes and memorials to Technoblade. The game's developers, Mojang Studios, also released a statement expressing their condolences and gratitude for Technoblade's contributions to the Minecraft community.

FIFA World Cup Records and Statistics

The FIFA World Cup is an international soccer tournament held every four years, featuring national teams from all over the world. The tournament has a rich history, and over the years, numerous records have been set and broken. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the records and statistics from the FIFA World Cup.

# List of Tournaments

There have been 22 FIFA World Cup tournaments held since the first one in 1930. The list of tournaments includes:

1. 1930 FIFA World Cup in Uruguay
2. 1934 FIFA World Cup in Italy
3. 1938 FIFA World Cup in France
4. 1950 FIFA World Cup in Brazil
5. 1954 FIFA World Cup in Switzerland
6. 1958 FIFA World Cup in Sweden
7. 1962 FIFA World Cup in Chile
8. 1966 FIFA World Cup in England
9. 1970 FIFA World Cup in Mexico
10. 1974 FIFA World Cup in West Germany
11. 1978 FIFA World Cup in Argentina
12. 1982 FIFA World Cup in Spain
13. 1986 FIFA World Cup in Mexico
14. 1990 FIFA World Cup in Italy
15. 1994 FIFA World Cup in the United States
16. 1998 FIFA World Cup in France
17. 2002 FIFA World Cup in South Korea and Japan
18. 2006 FIFA World Cup in Germany
19. 2010 FIFA World Cup in South Africa
20. 2014 FIFA World Cup in Brazil
21. 2018 FIFA World Cup in Russia
22. 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar

# Overall Team Records

This section provides an overview of the overall team records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Titles

Brazil holds the record for the most FIFA World Cup titles, having won the tournament five times (1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, and 2002).

## Most Finishes in the Top Two

Germany and Brazil are tied for the most finishes in the top two, with each team having achieved this feat on eight occasions.

## Most Second-Place Finishes

Germany holds the record for the most second-place finishes, having finished as runners-up on four occasions (1954, 1966, 1982, and 2002).

## Most World Cup Appearances

Brazil holds the record for the most World Cup appearances, having participated in every tournament since the inaugural event in 1930.

## Most Consecutive Championships

Italy and Brazil are tied for the most consecutive championships, with each team having won the tournament twice in a row (Italy in 1934 and 1938, and Brazil in 1958 and 1962).

## Most Consecutive Finishes in the Top Two

Germany holds the record for the most consecutive finishes in the top two, having achieved this feat on four occasions (1982, 1986, 1990, and 1998).

## Longest Gap Between Successive Titles

The longest gap between successive titles is held by Brazil, who won the tournament in 1970 and then again in 1994, a gap of 24 years.

## Longest Gap Between Successive Appearances in the Top Two

The longest gap between successive appearances in the top two is held by the Netherlands, who finished as runners-up in 1974 and then again in 2010, a gap of 36 years.

## Longest Gap Between Successive Appearances at the FIFA World Cup

The longest gap between successive appearances at the FIFA World Cup is held by Egypt, who participated in the tournament in 1934 and then again in 1990, a gap of 56 years.

## Most Consecutive Failed Qualification Attempts

The most consecutive failed qualification attempts is held by Luxembourg, who failed to qualify for the tournament on 20 consecutive occasions (1966-2018).

## Worst Finish by Defending Champions

The worst finish by defending champions is held by France, who were eliminated in the group stage in 2002, and by Spain, who were eliminated in the group stage in 2014.

# Players

This section provides an overview of the records held by players in the FIFA World Cup.

## Most Appearances

The record for the most appearances in the FIFA World Cup is held by Lothar Matthäus, who played in 25 matches for Germany between 1982 and 1998.

## Most Championships

The record for the most championships won by a player is held by Pelé, who won the tournament three times with Brazil (1958, 1962, and 1970).

## Most Appearances in a World Cup Final

The record for the most appearances in a World Cup final is held by Cafu, who played in three finals for Brazil (1994, 1998, and 2002).

## Youngest Player

The youngest player to participate in the FIFA World Cup is Norman Whiteside, who played for Northern Ireland in 1982 at the age of 17 years and 41 days.

## Youngest Player in a Final

The youngest player to participate in a World Cup final is Pelé, who played for Brazil in 1958 at the age of 17 years and 249 days.

## Oldest Player

The oldest player to participate in the FIFA World Cup is Faryd Mondragón, who played for Colombia in 2014 at the age of 43 years and 3 days.

## Oldest Player in a Final

The oldest player to participate in a World Cup final is Dino Zoff, who played for Italy in 1982 at the age of 40 years and 133 days.

# Goalscoring

This section provides an overview of the goalscoring records in the FIFA World Cup.

## Individual

### Top Goalscorers

Malaysia at the 2023 SEA Games

The 2023 Southeast Asian Games, officially known as the 32nd Southeast Asian Games, was a Southeast Asian multi-sport event that took place in Phnom Penh, Cambodia from 5 to 17 May 2023. Malaysia sent a contingent of athletes to compete in the games.

Background

### Preparations

Malaysia's preparations for the 2023 SEA Games began in early 2022, with the Olympic Council of Malaysia (OCM) and the National Sports Council (NSC) working together to identify and select athletes for the games. The Malaysian government also provided financial support for the athletes' training and preparation.

### Broadcasters

The 2023 SEA Games were broadcast live in Malaysia by Astro, a Malaysian satellite television provider. Astro also provided live streaming of the games on its Astro Go app.

Medal summary

### Medal by sport

Malaysia won a total of 136 medals in 32 sports at the 2023 SEA Games. The sports that contributed the most medals to Malaysia's tally were athletics, badminton, and swimming.

Malaysia won medals on all 12 days of competition at the 2023 SEA Games. The most medals won by Malaysia in a single day was 23, which occurred on 12 May 2023.

A total of 156 Malaysian athletes won medals at the 2023 SEA Games. The most successful Malaysian athlete was sprinter Muhammad Azeem Fahmi, who won three gold medals in the 100m and 200m events.

article:
Jackass Forever
================

Jackass Forever is a 2022 American action comedy film directed by Jeff Tremaine and starring Johnny Knoxville, Steve-O, Dave England, Wee Man, Danger Ehren, and Preston Lacy. The film is the fourth installment in the Jackass film series and features the return of the original cast, as well as several new faces.

Synopsis
--------

The film follows the Jackass crew as they perform various stunts and pranks, often pushing the boundaries of physical comedy and absurdity. The movie features a mix of traditional Jackass stunts, as well as more elaborate and complex set pieces. The crew also engages in various celebrity guest appearances and interactions, adding to the film's humor and entertainment value.

Cast
-----

The main cast of Jackass Forever includes:

* Johnny Knoxville as himself
* Steve-O as himself
* Dave England as himself
* Wee Man as himself
* Danger Ehren as himself
* Preston Lacy as himself

Guest appearances
-----------------

The film features several celebrity guest appearances, including:

* Machine Gun Kelly
* Shaquille O'Neal
* Tony Hawk
* Rob Dyrdek
* Eric André

Crew
-----

The crew of Jackass Forever includes:

* Director: Jeff Tremaine
* Producers: Spike Jonze, Johnny Knoxville, and Jeff Tremaine
* Screenplay: Andrew Weinberg, Colton Dunn, and Derek Freda
* Cinematography: Dimitry Elyashkevich
* Editing: Seth Flaum, Matt Kosinski, and Matthew Probst

Production
----------

### Development

The development of Jackass Forever began in 2019, with the original cast and crew reuniting to work on the film. The movie was initially set to be released in 2021, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, production was delayed and the release date was pushed back to 2022.

### Bam Margera's firing

In February 2021, it was announced that Bam Margera, a longtime member of the Jackass crew, had been fired from the film due to his struggles with addiction and personal issues. Margera had been a key member of the Jackass team since the early days of the franchise, and his departure was met with sadness and support from his former castmates.

### Casting

The casting process for Jackass Forever involved a mix of returning cast members and new faces. The film features several new cast members, including Jasper Dolphin and Rachel Wolfson, who join the Jackass crew for the first time.

### Filming

Filming for Jackass Forever took place in 2021, with the crew shooting on location in various parts of the United States. The film's stunts and set pieces were designed to be more elaborate and complex than previous Jackass films, with a focus on pushing the boundaries of physical comedy and absurdity.

### Injuries

As with previous Jackass films, the cast and crew of Jackass Forever suffered several injuries during filming. The most notable injury was sustained by Johnny Knoxville, who broke his ankle during a stunt gone wrong. Other cast members also suffered various injuries, including concussions, broken bones, and other minor ailments.

Release
--------

Jackass Forever was released in theaters on February 4, 2022. The film received a wide release, with showings in over 3,000 theaters across the United States.

### Home media

The film was released on digital platforms on March 22, 2022, and on DVD and Blu-ray on April 5, 2022.

Reception
----------

### Box office

Jackass Forever was a commercial success, grossing over $57 million at the domestic box office and over $100 million worldwide. The film's opening weekend saw it debut at number one at the box office, with a total of $23.5 million in ticket sales.

### Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the cast's chemistry and the film's humor. The movie holds a 74% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 6.2/10.

Jackass 4.5
------------

In May 2022, it was announced that a spin-off film titled Jackass 4.5 would be released on Netflix. The film features unused footage from Jackass Forever, as well as new material shot specifically for the spin-off. Jackass 4.5 was released on Netflix on May 20, 2022.

References
----------

article:
Assassination of John F. Kennedy

John F. Kennedy, the 35th President of the United States, was assassinated on November 22, 1963, in Dallas, Texas. The event shocked the nation and the world, and it remains one of the most significant and debated topics in modern American history. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the events surrounding the assassination, the investigations that followed, and the impact it had on the nation and the world.

#Background

##Kennedy

John F. Kennedy was born on May 29, 1917, in Brookline, Massachusetts. He graduated from Harvard University and served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. After the war, he entered politics and was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1946. He served in the House for six years before being elected to the U.S. Senate in 1952. In 1960, he was elected as the 35th President of the United States, defeating Republican candidate Richard Nixon.

##Oswald

Lee Harvey Oswald was born on October 18, 1939, in New Orleans, Louisiana. He grew up in a troubled home and dropped out of high school in the ninth grade. He joined the U.S. Marine Corps in 1956 and served for three years before being honorably discharged. After his discharge, he moved to the Soviet Union, where he lived for two years before returning to the United States. He worked at various jobs, including as a typesetter at the Dallas Times Herald.

#November 22

##Kennedy's arrival in Dallas and route to Dealey Plaza

On November 22, 1963, President Kennedy arrived at Dallas Love Field on Air Force One. He was accompanied by First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy, Texas Governor John Connally, and his wife, Nellie. The presidential motorcade was scheduled to take the Kennedys to a luncheon at the Dallas Trade Mart, where the President was to give a speech. The motorcade route took the President through Dealey Plaza, a public park in downtown Dallas.

##Shooting

article:
2022 UK Championship

The 2022 UK Championship was a professional snooker tournament that took place from 12 to 20 November 2022 at the York Barbican in York, England. It was the seventh ranking event of the 2022-2023 snooker season and the 46th edition of the UK Championship.

# Format

The tournament was played in a knockout format, with 128 players competing in the main draw. The top 16 players in the world rankings were seeded, with the remaining 112 players qualifying through a series of qualifying rounds. The tournament was played over eight days, with the final taking place on 20 November.

## Prize fund

The total prize fund for the tournament was £850,000, with the winner receiving £170,000. The prize fund was distributed as follows:

* Winner: £170,000
* Runner-up: £80,000
* Semi-finalists: £40,000
* Quarter-finalists: £24,500
* Last 16: £17,000
* Last 32: £12,000
* Last 64: £6,500
* Last 128: £3,000

# Summary

The 2022 UK Championship was won by Mark Allen, who defeated Ding Junhui 10-7 in the final. It was Allen's first UK Championship title and his second ranking title of the season. The tournament saw a number of upsets, including the defeat of world number one Ronnie O'Sullivan in the quarter-finals.

## Qualifying rounds

The qualifying rounds took place from 5 to 10 November at the Ponds Forge International Sports Centre in Sheffield. The qualifying rounds were played in a knockout format, with the winners advancing to the main draw.

## First round

The first round took place from 12 to 14 November, with the winners advancing to the second round. The round saw a number of upsets, including the defeat of world number 16 Gary Wilson.

## Second round

The second round took place from 14 to 16 November, with the winners advancing to the third round. The round saw the defeat of world number 9 Kyren Wilson.

## Quarter-finals

The quarter-finals took place on 17 November, with the winners advancing to the semi-finals. The round saw the defeat of world number 1 Ronnie O'Sullivan.

## Semi-finals

The semi-finals took place on 18 and 19 November, with the winners advancing to the final. The round saw the defeat of world number 3 Judd Trump.

## Final

The final took place on 20 November, with Mark Allen defeating Ding Junhui 10-7.

Greece's Next Top Model Season 5

Greece's Next Top Model Season 5 was the fifth season of the Greek reality television series Greece's Next Top Model. The show premiered on September 13, 2018, on Skai TV and concluded on May 31, 2019. The season featured a new host, Vicky Kaya, and a new judging panel.

The first five episodes of the season featured the contestants auditioning for a spot in the competition. The contestants were put through various challenges, including runway walks, photo shoots, and interviews with the judges.

article:
2022 United States House of Representatives Elections in California

The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in California were held on November 8, 2022, to elect the 52 members of the U.S. House of Representatives from California. The elections coincided with the 2022 midterm elections, the California gubernatorial election, and the 2022 California State Senate election.

# Overview

## Statewide

California has 52 congressional districts, the most of any state in the United States. The 2022 elections were the first to take place after the 2020 United States Census, which resulted in California losing one congressional seat. As a result, the state's congressional districts were redrawn during the 2020 redistricting cycle.

## District

Each district elected one member to the U.S. House of Representatives. The elections were held under the nonpartisan blanket primary system, in which the top two candidates, regardless of party affiliation, advanced to the general election.

# District 1

## Candidates

### Advanced to general

* Doug LaMalfa (Republican)
* Max Steiner (Democratic)

### Eliminated in primary

* David Peterson (Republican)
* Rose Penelope Yee (Democratic)

## Endorsements

* Doug LaMalfa (Republican) was endorsed by the National Rifle Association and the California Republican Party.
* Max Steiner (Democratic) was endorsed by the California Democratic Party.

## Predictions

* The Cook Political Report rated the district as "Solid Republican".
* Inside Elections rated the district as "Safe Republican".

## Results

* Doug LaMalfa (Republican) won the general election with 62.5% of the vote.

# District 2

## Candidates

### Advanced to general

* Jared Huffman (Democratic)
* Douglas Brower (Republican)

### Eliminated in primary

* Beth Hampson (Democratic)
* Chris Coulombe (Republican)

## Endorsements

* Jared Huffman (Democratic) was endorsed by the California Democratic Party and the Sierra Club.
* Douglas Brower (Republican) was endorsed by the California Republican Party.

## Predictions

* The Cook Political Report rated the district as "Solid Democratic".
* Inside Elections rated the district as "Safe Democratic".

## Results

* Jared Huffman (Democratic) won the general election with 74.5% of the vote.

# District 3

## Candidates

### Advanced to general

* Kevin Kiley (Republican)
* Kermit Jones (Democratic)

### Eliminated in primary

* Scott Jones (Republican)
* David Peterson (Republican)
* Brynne Kennedy (Democratic)

### Withdrew

* Sean Feucht (Republican)

## Endorsements

* Kevin Kiley (Republican) was endorsed by the California Republican Party and the National Rifle Association.
* Kermit Jones (Democratic) was endorsed by the California Democratic Party.

## Predictions

* The Cook Political Report rated the district as "Likely Republican".
* Inside Elections rated the district as "Lean Republican".

## Polling

* A poll conducted by the California Target Book in September 2022 found Kevin Kiley leading Kermit Jones by 5 points.

## Results

* Kevin Kiley (Republican) won the general election with 52.5% of the vote.

# District 4

## Candidates

### Advanced to general

* Mike Thompson (Democratic)
* Matt Brock (Republican)

### Eliminated in primary

* Chris Bish (Democratic)
* Scott Giblin (Republican)

## Endorsements

* Mike Thompson (Democratic) was endorsed by the California Democratic Party and the National Education Association.
* Matt Brock (Republican) was endorsed by the California Republican Party.

## Predictions

* The Cook Political Report rated the district as "Solid Democratic".
* Inside Elections rated the district as "Safe Democratic".

## Results

* Mike Thompson (Democratic) won the general election with 67.5% of the vote.

# District 5

## Candidates

### Advanced to general

* Tom McClintock (Republican)
* Mike Barkley (Democratic)

### Eliminated in primary

* Jason Kassel (Democratic)
* Nathan Magsig (Republican)

### Withdrew

* Sean Feucht (Republican)

### Declined

* Darrell Issa (Republican)

## Endorsements

* Tom McClintock (Republican) was endorsed by the California Republican Party and the National Rifle Association.
* Mike Barkley (Democratic) was endorsed by the California Democratic Party.

## Predictions

* The Cook Political Report rated the district as "Solid Republican".
* Inside Elections rated the district as "Safe Republican".

## Results

* Tom McClintock (Republican) won the general election with 61.5% of the vote.
